metadata.titleEn: Manual observation of meteorological data in Hulugou sub-basin of Heihe River Basin (2013)
metadata.description:
1. Data overview:
In 2013, the standard meteorological field of qilian station, Cold and Arid Regions Environmental and Engineering Research Institute, observed various meteorological elements manually at time of 8:00, 14:00 and 20:00 every day.
2. Data content:
The data include dry bulb temperature, wet bulb temperature, maximum temperature, minimum temperature, surface temperature (0cm), shallow surface temperature (5cm, 10cm, 15cm, 20cm), maximum surface temperature, minimum surface temperature.
3. Space and time range:
Geographical coordinates: longitude: 99.9e; Latitude: 38.3n; Height: 2980 m.
metadata.instructions: Data file name: hulugou basin 2013 meteorological manual observation data set.xlsx; it can be viewed and edited by WPS or Excel software.

background: Understanding cryospheric hydrology and the effects of cryospheric changes on river runoff is critical for sustainable water management especially in arid inland river basins such as those in northwest China where water resources mainly come from alpine areas. The Earth’s cryosphere is facing rapid changes in the duration, extent, and mass of snow and ice, which have had multiple impacts on the environment across a range of temporal and spatial scales. Changes in mountain snow, glaciers, and permafrost have resulted in significant downstream impacts in terms of the quantity, seasonality, and quality of water. This shrinkage has modified the water cycle and river discharge in cold regions and caused the rise of global mean sea level. Serving as a solid reservoir for many endorheic and exorheic basins, the mountain cryosphere is the regulator of major rivers and provides most of the water resources in arid regions in China and its neighboring countries. However, because of inadequate observation data and the lack of knowledge about many aspects of cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales in alpine regions, the significance of the impacts of cryospheric changes and the severity of their consequences remain unclear in China.
research objective: The scientific objective of the CHOICE is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in the lower arid regions. Four key science questions have been identified: The spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation need to be determined. The effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow need to be determined. The effects of changes in the vegetation pattern in the vertical landscape zones on water balance and river runoff in the mountains must be assessed. A suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology is needed in mountainous areas.
challenges: Understanding such changes in these vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges because of their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors.
methods: Each AWS features the long-term monitoring of the following meteorological variables: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature (LST), soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. We also conducted long-term standard meteorological field (SMF) manual observations for reference to those obtained at AWS. The total discharge has been monitored by a continuously stream-gauging station at the catchment outlet since 2009. From 2009 to 2012, we also manually used the float protocol and a stopwatch to estimate the nonfreezing period discharge in a meadow subcatchment and a moraine–talus subcatchment. To apply hydrological models in the alpine catchment, we have obtained long-term continuous soil parameter data in the soil pit synchronously with those collected at AWS. An SI-111 infrared radiometer (Apogee Instr. Inc.) was used to measure the LST. During the early stage of the CHOICE, evapotranspiration was measured with two manual weighing microlysimeters, which were 40 cm in depth and 31.5 cm in diameter and were installed in the SMF at the Hulu-1 field on 1 July 2009 with an electronic scale of 2 g (0.026 mm) in precision. With the development of the CHOICE, five automatic microlysimeters (CHOICE-LYS40, T&D) were arranged in the same field as the AWS of the Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 field in August 2013. An EC150 system (Campbell Scientific Inc.) was installed on a lattice mast at 5.8 m at the Hulu-2 field in September 2011. Four cluster wells were installed in 2011 and 2014 for groundwater monitoring and sampling. On fixed-point scale, six SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors (Campbell Scientific Inc.) measure snow depth synchronously with AWS. In this system, three thermistor cables were installed that crossed the riverbed–water, water–ice, and ice–air interfaces. We conduct the work of precipitation intercomparisons by referring to the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO using pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauge. Precipitation measurements in the Hulu catchment were performed with six total rain-weighing sensors (TRwS204, MPS System Ltd) with a single alter shield and synchronized with AWS. Fourteen LST observation sites with similar elevations but different aspects and slopes were built around the Hulu-3 field. Two LST observation sites were built to analyze the influences of plants on LST. To study the runoff process of canopy precipitation to surface runoff in different landscapes, two runoff fields (shrubs and meadows) (15 by 3 m) were established at a shrub-encroached alpine meadow hillslope in September 2010. Four methods were used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in the Hulu-1 field including a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer (Hood IL-2700, Germany), and the ring cutter method. Groundwater samples used for isotope analysis were collected from 12 wells between 2014 and 2016, and stream water samples were collected from 12 sites that were approximately evenly distributed from upstream to downstream between 2011 and 2016. A Picarro GasScouter G4301 gas concentration analyzer with a re-entry control system and six respiration chambers installed on the permafrost zone of the Hulu catchment in August 2017. The observation period of canopy precipitation interception began in June 2010. A total of four sap flow sensors (CAF, ECOMATIK) were installed to estimate transpiration. Variations in the diversity of the soil microbial community under meadow, shrub, marshy meadow, and moraine–talus were observed along an elevation gradient in the Hulu catchment in July 2013. An AWS was erected at the top of the glacier (4817 m asl) in September 2015; the site is not affected by the surrounding mountains. To obtain reliable turbulent data, EC system measurements were made adjacent to the AWS at a height of 4 m beginning in October 2017. To harvest the water contained in fog, five identical standard fog collectors were installed at Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 in July 2014. A warming simulation experiment was begun in September 2016. Two flight campaigns were performed in the Hulu catchment.
findings: In recent years, a series of studies have been published using the CHOICE sharing platform data, and a number of researchers have used the CHOICE data for studies of alpine meteorology, cryospheric hydrology, groundwater, soils, and isotopes. According to the six AWS of the CHOICE obtained throughout the Hulu catchment and peripheral precipitation data from five China Meteorological Administration stations (Zhangye, Minle, Sunan, Qilian, and Yeniugou), two or more yearly EMPs exist in the northern Qilian Mountains. A diminished accumulation zone will result in a reduction in the transport and expansion of the glaciers, and then the glaciers will have to retreat to limit themselves to reduce ablation. Based on 10-yr observations in the western cold regions of China, especially those obtained in the Upper Hei River basin (UHR), a new CBHM was created to evaluate the effects of cryospheric changes on stream flow from the UHR. In the past 50 yr, river runoff has generally shown an increasing trend as a result of increased rainfall, snowfall, and glacial runoff in the cold regions of western China.

Definition.Question: What does 'manual observation' mean in the context of meteorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of meteorological data collection, 'manual observation' refers to the practice of collecting various meteorological variables at set times of the day (e.g., 8:00, 14:00, 20:00) by human observers, as opposed to using automated systems. This method involves directly measuring weather elements like dry bulb temperature, wet bulb temperature, maximum and minimum temperatures, and ground temperatures at various depths.

Definition.Question: What are 'automatic microlysimeters' and how are they used in environmental data collection?
Definition.Answer: Automatic microlysimeters are devices used in environmental data collection to measure evapotranspiration by continuously monitoring the weight of a soil sample, which reflects the water loss due to evaporation and plant transpiration. These devices provide precise measurements over time and were installed in the Hulu catchment to assess water movement and loss in different fields.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using 'Sonic Ranging Sensors' in measuring snow depth in meteorological studies?
Definition.Answer: Sonic Ranging Sensors, such as the SR50A, are used in meteorological studies to measure snow depth accurately by emitting sound waves and calculating the time it takes for the waves to reflect back from the surface. This technology allows for accurate and continuous monitoring of snow accumulation and changes over time, which is crucial for understanding snow dynamics and their impact on hydrological processes.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about cryospheric changes and their impact on water resources from the observed temperature and precipitation patterns in a mountainous region?
Interpretation.Answer: Cryospheric changes in mountainous regions, such as alterations in snow duration, glacier mass, and permafrost, significantly impact water resources by affecting the quantity, seasonality, and quality of water. These changes are inferred from temperature and precipitation patterns, which show how the cryosphere acts as a solid reservoir regulating major rivers and providing water resources in arid areas. The data collection methods, like those involving AWS and SMF observations, help understand these impacts despite challenges like remote locations and sparse observations.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges do researchers face in accurately measuring precipitation in mountainous areas, and how do these challenges affect the interpretation of hydrometeorological data?
Interpretation.Answer: Researchers face challenges like biases and errors in precipitation measurements due to the complex terrain and sparse observation networks in mountainous areas. These challenges hinder the accurate interpretation of hydrometeorological data, affecting the understanding of precipitation distribution and its effects on hydrological processes. Methods like the WMO Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment and using multiple rain-weighing sensors aim to improve measurement accuracy and data reliability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the remoteness and sparse observations challenges in collecting meteorological data in alpine regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Understanding changes in vulnerable regions such as alpine areas is challenging due to their remoteness and sparse observations. This is compounded by significant biases and errors in precipitation observations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for manual observations in addition to automated weather station data in meteorological studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Manual observations in standard meteorological fields are conducted as a reference to those obtained at automated weather stations (AWS), likely due to the need for data verification and to account for potential discrepancies in automated data collection.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the significant biases and errors in precipitation observations in mountainous regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Precipitation observations in remote and alpine regions are beset with significant biases and errors due to the challenges inherent in the terrain, the lack of dense observation networks, and the complexity of accurately measuring precipitation in diverse weather conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes on hydrological data accuracy when utilizing both manual and automatic weather station observations in mountainous regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing both manual and automatic weather station observations can enhance the accuracy of hydrological data by providing a comprehensive dataset which includes long-term monitoring of meteorological variables and manual observations for reference. This dual approach can help mitigate biases and errors in precipitation observations, which are common challenges in remote and vulnerable regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the introduction of microlysimeters impact the understanding of evapotranspiration processes in alpine catchments?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The introduction of microlysimeters, both manual and automatic, allows for precise measurements of evapotranspiration in alpine catchments. This can lead to a better understanding of the water balance and the effects of climate and land cover changes on water resources, aiding in the assessment of hydrological processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intended purpose behind collecting comprehensive observation data to determine hydrological processes in mountainous regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The scientific objective is to obtain comprehensive observation data to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in lower arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to establish a reliable distributed hydrological model in mountainous areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: A suitable distributed hydrological model is needed to include cryospheric hydrology in mountainous areas to assess the impacts of changes in vegetation patterns and cryospheric changes on water balance and river runoff.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps for setting up and calibrating automatic weather stations (AWS) to ensure accurate long-term monitoring of meteorological variables in alpine regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Each AWS is equipped to monitor air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation. It requires precise installation and calibration to ensure accurate data collection. An SI-111 infrared radiometer is used for measuring land surface temperature, and various sensors such as SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors and rain-weighing sensors are synchronized with AWS to measure snow depth and precipitation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in alpine catchments, and how do these measurements contribute to hydrological modeling?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Four methods are used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity: a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer, and the ring cutter method. These measurements are crucial for understanding soil-water interactions and are used in hydrological modeling to simulate water flow and storage processes in the catchment.

Enablement.Question: What technology has enabled the collection of long-term meteorological data in mountainous cryospheric regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of Automatic Weather Stations (AWS) equipped with sensors for air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount has enabled the collection of long-term meteorological data in mountainous cryospheric regions.

Enablement.Question: How do soil parameter data and its continuous collection enable the application of hydrological models in alpine catchments?
Enablement.Answer: The continuous collection of soil parameter data synchronously with data from Automatic Weather Stations (AWS) provides essential inputs for hydrological models, enabling their application in alpine catchments by accounting for soil temperature, moisture, and related factors that influence hydrological processes.

Expectation.Question: Why is there a significant challenge in understanding cryospheric changes in remote alpine regions?
Expectation.Answer: Understanding cryospheric changes in remote alpine regions has posed significant challenges due to their remoteness and sparse observations, leading to biases and errors in precipitation data.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected outcomes of using various data collection methods, such as manual observations and automated systems, in cryospheric hydrology studies?
Expectation.Answer: The expected outcomes of using a combination of manual observations and automated systems in cryospheric hydrology studies include obtaining comprehensive data about meteorological variables, soil parameters, and precipitation, which can help in understanding hydrological processes and the effects of climate and cryosphere changes on water resources.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the introduction of new technological advancements improve data collection for hydrological models in alpine catchments?
Judgmental.Answer: The introduction of new technological advancements, such as high-precision sensors for soil moisture and temperature, automatic microlysimeters for evapotranspiration, and improved groundwater monitoring systems, could significantly enhance data collection for hydrological models. These technologies can provide more accurate and continuous data, which is crucial for understanding complex hydrological processes in alpine catchments.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how manual observations are integrated with automated weather station data in meteorological studies.
Assertion.Answer: Manual observations in meteorological studies are used as a reference to validate and calibrate data collected from automated weather stations (AWS). These manual observations provide a standard against which AWS measurements can be compared, ensuring their accuracy and reliability.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in measuring precipitation accurately in remote mountainous regions.
Assertion.Answer: Measuring precipitation accurately in remote mountainous regions is challenging due to the remoteness and sparse observations, which can lead to significant biases and errors. Special methods, such as precipitation intercomparisons with pit gauges and DFIR gauge, are employed to address these challenges.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the different methods used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in alpine environments.
Assertion.Answer: Various methods, including single-ring infiltrometers, double-ring infiltrometers, Hood infiltrometers, and the ring cutter method, are used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity. These methods help capture the diverse soil characteristics and conditions present in alpine environments.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the various meteorological variables that are monitored using different data collection methods in this field and discuss their significance.
Request/Directive.Answer: In this field, various meteorological variables are monitored using both automatic weather stations (AWS) and manual methods. These variables include air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature (LST), soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. The significance of these variables lies in their ability to help researchers understand hydrological processes in mountainous regions and evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on hydrology and water resources in arid regions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in data collection for cryospheric hydrology in remote regions and suggest possible solutions to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges faced in data collection for cryospheric hydrology in remote regions include the remoteness and sparse observations, as well as significant biases and errors in precipitation observations. Possible solutions to address these challenges could involve increasing the density of observation networks, improving the accuracy of precipitation measurement techniques, and employing advanced remote sensing technologies to supplement ground-based observations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could be expanded or refined to improve the understanding of cryospheric changes and their impacts on hydrology in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets that could be expanded or refined include those related to long-term soil parameter data, snow depth measurements, and precipitation intercomparisons. Additionally, datasets from automatic microlysimeters and groundwater monitoring systems could be further enhanced to improve the understanding of cryospheric changes and their impacts on hydrology in arid regions.
